questions.question: Which of the following sets of characteristics can ALL be used to classify and sort matter?

answers.explanation: Matter can be classified using any observable property, including shape, colour and state.

questions.question: In the syringe investigation, which state of matter could be compressed most easily?

answers.explanation: Because the particles in a gas are far apart, air can be forced into a smaller volume when pressure is applied.

questions.question: Give a scientific definition of matter.

answers.content: Matter is anything that has mass and takes up space (has volume).
answers.explanation: Accept wording that clearly states both mass and volume as essential features of matter.

questions.question: What common property was used to group coins, aluminium foil, car parts and water tanks together during the lesson?

answers.explanation: All the listed items are metallic objects.

questions.question: When you tried to push the plunger of the syringe filled with water all the way down, what happened?

answers.content: The water did not compress noticeably
answers.explanation: Liquids are almost incompressible because their particles are already close together.

answers.content: The water changed into a solid

questions.question: The ‘Ooho’ water bottle shown in the video is mainly made from:

answers.content: A biodegradable brown-algae film containing water
answers.explanation: The edible membrane is produced from brown algae; it holds liquid water inside.

questions.question: List the three main states of matter discussed in the lesson.

answers.explanation: Order not important; all three states must be named to receive full marks.

questions.question: Plasma is able to conduct electricity because its particles are:

answers.explanation: In plasma, high energy strips electrons off atoms, creating charged particles that carry electric current.

questions.question: Draw and label one everyday example of a solid, a liquid and a gas. Next to each drawing, list at least two observable properties that justify why it belongs to that state of matter.

answers.content: Student drawings showing three labelled examples with properties (e.g. brick—rigid, keeps shape; water—flows, takes shape of container; steam—fills space, compressible).
answers.explanation: Award full marks for correctly identifying all three states with accurate properties; partial marks may be given as per rubric.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a property of gases discussed in the lesson?

answers.content: Gases take the shape of their container

answers.explanation: Unlike solids, gases do not keep a fixed shape; they expand to fill any container.

questions.question: In Investigation 2 (Water-proof Paper), why did the tissue stay dry when the cup was lowered straight down into the water?

answers.content: Air trapped in the cup took up space and prevented water from reaching the tissue
answers.explanation: The trapped gas (air) occupied the space inside the inverted cup so water could not enter.

answers.content: Water cannot rise inside transparent plastics

questions.question: During the Gas Bag investigation, the bag inflated because

answers.content: heat from your hands expanded the air already in the bag
vinegar and baking-soda reacted to produce carbon-dioxide gas
answers.explanation: The acid–base reaction releases CO₂, which takes up more space and inflates the bag.

answers.content: oxygen leaked into the bag through the plastic

questions.question: Why does a balloon filled with helium rise in air?

answers.content: Helium is less dense (lighter) than the surrounding air, so the balloon experiences an upward buoyant force and rises.

questions.question: Describe TWO different ways students observed moving air in Investigation 1 and explain what each observation demonstrated about gas behaviour.

answers.content: Example: (1) Standing in front of a fan – moving air could be felt on skin, showing that gases can flow. (2) Pumping a bike pump – resistance increased when the nozzle was blocked, demonstrating that gases can be compressed and have pressure.

questions.question: The ability to smell freshly-baked cookies from another room is evidence that a gas

answers.content: can flow from one place to another
answers.explanation: Odour molecules travel through the air, showing that gases flow and mix.

questions.question: Suggest ONE improvement to the Moving Air investigation that would allow students to collect quantitative (numerical) data about gas behaviour.

answers.content: Attach a small anemometer or wind-speed sensor in front of the fan to record the speed of the moving air in metres per second.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram showing an inverted cup under water with trapped air. Include labels for water, trapped air, tissue, and direction of any escaping bubbles.

answers.content: A labelled diagram with cup, water surface, air pocket, dry tissue, and arrows for bubbles escaping receives full marks.

questions.question: What is viscosity?

answers.content: A measure of how quickly a liquid evaporates
A measure of how easily a liquid flows
answers.explanation: Viscosity describes the internal resistance of a liquid to flow; high-viscosity liquids flow slowly, low-viscosity liquids flow quickly.

answers.content: A measure of the temperature of a liquid
A measure of how much a liquid weighs

questions.question: When you compare the "runniness" of honey, shampoo and custard on the same tilted tray, which ONE variable are you intentionally changing to make it a fair test?

answers.content: The amount of time you observe the samples

answers.explanation: For a fair test only the type of liquid should change; all other conditions stay the same.

questions.question: Give TWO practical actions you would take to ensure your viscosity "race" is a fair test.

answers.content: Sample answer: 1) Use the same volume of each liquid. 2) Tilt the tray to the same angle for every trial (or keep distance and surface the same).
answers.explanation: Students should mention keeping all but one variable constant, e.g. equal volumes, identical surface/distance, identical tilt angle, identical start line.

questions.question:
A group timed three liquids travelling 20 cm down the tray:
• Honey – 12 s
• Custard – 8 s
• Shampoo – 6 s
Which liquid has the HIGHEST viscosity?

answers.explanation: Honey took the longest time to travel the same distance, so it flows slowest and therefore has the highest viscosity.

answers.content: All three have the same viscosity

questions.question: Explain why the new squeezable Vegemite must have a LOWER viscosity than Vegemite that comes in a jar.

answers.content: Sample answer: To be squeezed through a nozzle, Vegemite needs to flow more easily. Reducing its viscosity (for example by adding water or removing some solids) lets it move under gentle pressure from the tube.
answers.explanation: Students should link the ability to squeeze/pour with lower viscosity and may describe thinning or formulation changes.

questions.question: Draw and label three everyday liquids ordered from LOWEST to HIGHEST viscosity, and write one sentence explaining your order.

answers.content: Expected: a labelled sequence such as water → cooking oil → honey with an explanation sentence (e.g. "Water flows fastest so it has the lowest viscosity, honey flows slowest so it has the highest").
answers.explanation: Award full marks for clearly ordered drawings/labels plus a correct viscosity justification; partial marks for partial accuracy.

questions.question: When most solids, liquids and gases are heated they:

answers.explanation: Adding heat energy makes particles move faster and spread out.

questions.question: Describe why the glass jug shatters when very cold water is poured onto its hot surface.

answers.content: The sudden cooling makes the outside of the glass contract quickly while the inside is still hot and expanded. This creates large stresses (thermal shock) that crack and shatter the brittle glass.
answers.explanation: Students must mention rapid temperature change, uneven contraction/expansion and resulting stress.

questions.question: In the self-inflating balloon investigation, the balloon inflates in hot water because:

answers.content: Air inside the bottle expands, raising the pressure and pushing into the balloon.
answers.explanation: Heating a gas increases its volume and pressure in a closed space.

answers.content: Water enters the bottle and blows up the balloon.
The rubber of the balloon contracts in heat.
Cold air is heavier than hot air.

questions.question: Why are expansion joints built into long bridges?

answers.content: To allow the bridge materials to expand and contract with temperature changes without cracking or buckling.
answers.explanation: Metals and concrete change length with temperature; joints prevent structural damage.

answers.content: To make the bridge look interesting
To reduce the weight of the bridge

questions.question: A jar lid loosens after being held under hot tap water. Explain why.

answers.content: The metal lid expands more than the glass jar when heated, increasing the gap between them so the lid can turn more easily.
answers.explanation: Thermal expansion of the metal reduces the friction seal.

questions.question: Which statement best explains how a liquid-in-glass thermometer works?

answers.content: The liquid expands when warmed, rising up the narrow tube; it contracts when cooled, falling back down.
answers.explanation: Thermal expansion/contraction of the liquid indicates temperature.

answers.content: The glass tube stretches when heated, pulling the liquid upward.
Heat causes bubbles that push the liquid up.
Electric sensors inside the tube detect temperature.

questions.question: Water ‘breaks the rules’ of expansion and contraction when it is cooled below 4 °C. What unusual behaviour does it show and why is this important for life on Earth?

answers.content: Instead of continuing to contract, water expands as it freezes, so ice is less dense than liquid water and floats. This insulates lakes and rivers, allowing aquatic life to survive beneath the ice in winter.
answers.explanation: Answer must include expansion on freezing, lower density, floating ice and ecological significance.

questions.question: Draw two labelled diagrams to show the air particles in the balloon experiment: one when the bottle is in hot water and one when it is in ice water. Use arrows or spacing to indicate particle movement and volume changes.

answers.content: Hot water diagram shows widely spaced, fast-moving particles filling balloon; cold water diagram shows closely spaced, slower particles with deflated balloon.
answers.explanation: Marks awarded for correctly representing expansion in heat and contraction in cold with clear labels.
